title: About Me
text:
My Journey
My interest in bioinformatics emerged from a fascination with how computational approaches can decode biological complexity. With a foundation in biomedical sciences and genomics, I’m now focused on building strong programming and data analysis skills to bridge wet-lab biology and computational research.
I’m working through bioinformatics problem sets, building analysis pipelines, and documenting my learning journey through this portfolio. My background includes teaching experience in gymnastics and education, which has strengthened my ability to break down complex concepts and communicate effectively.

title: About Me
text:
Interests Beyond Science


Scuba Diving
Open-water and nitrox certified. Diving demands methodical preparation, situational awareness, and staying calm under pressure — skills that translate directly to research and problem solving.


Martial Arts
Black belt in Taekwondo, with training in Muay Thai and Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu. Martial arts taught me that mastery is a process, not a destination — a philosophy I carry into learning bioinformatics.


Yu-Gi-Oh
Competitive player focused on deck building and strategic play. The game demands pattern recognition, probabilistic thinking, and adapting under pressure.


Writing
Currently writing Useless Man: Embracing the Exiled Self — a philosophical exploration of identity, purpose, and the freedom found in not fitting the expected mold.

title: About Me
text:
What’s Next
I’m actively seeking opportunities in bioinformatics, computational biology, or data science where I can apply my growing technical skills and contribute to meaningful research. I’m particularly interested in genomics, algorithm development, and data-driven biological discovery.
Open to: Full-time positions, internships, collaborations, and freelance projects

title: Research
text: Undergraduate research grounded in neuroscience, molecular biology and bioinformatics. My work focuses on applying quantitative methods to biological questions — connecting wet-lab context with data-driven analysis.

title: Research
text:
Selected Undergraduate Research

Digitization, Tracing, and Quantification of CGRP-IR Axons in the Nociceptive Cardiac Nervous System

Role: Undergraduate Researcher
Advisor: Dr. Zixi Cheng · Department of Biomedical Sciences · University of Central Florida
Duration: June 2022 – May 2023
Presentation: Student Scholar Symposium · University of Central Florida · March 28, 2023


This study used C57BL/6J mice which were sacrificed and perfused through the left ventricle with 4°C Zamboni’s fixative, the heart was then harvested and dissected into the right and left atria and ventricles. The samples were immunohistochemically (IHC) stained for calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP). The tissues were then prepared as flat-mounts and scanned using automated color fluorescence and confocal microscopy. The samples that were scanned for CGRP-IR axons – at 488 nm – were digitized and traced using a 3D neuron reconstruction software and finally quantified using ImageJ2 (Fiji). Within CGRP-IR axons, 2D and 3D digitalized axonal tracings have not been reported in the whole mouse heart, as a result, this data expanded that very limited dataset.

Download Poster (PDF)
Methods & Tools
Fluorescence/Confocal Microscopy · Neurolucida · ImageJ · GraphPad Prism · Microsoft Word/Excel · Adobe Photoshop/Illustrator · BioRendeer



Mutant U1A-RNA Binding Kinetics with Surface Plasmon Resonance

Role: Undergraduate Researcher
Advisor: Dr. Robert Borgon · Department of Biomedical Sciences · University of Central Florida
Duration: August 2022 – May 2023
Presentation: Amy Zeh High Impact Practice Student Showcase · University of Central Florida · April 19, 2023


This study involved the use of U1A which is a protein subunit that is part of the U1 snRNP and binds to U1 hairpin II (U1hpII) of the snRNA that associates with the U1 snRNP. The U1A wildtype is compared to point mutations incorporated into the mutated protein to find amino acids residues that have significance in binding. The binding efficacy is measured through kinetic data produced via surface plasmon resonance (SPR) which flows U1hpII over a NTA chip that has a ligand (i.e., U1A wildtype or mutants) immobilized to it via a His-tag. The produced binding curves will show the association and disassociation phases in which a mathematical model was applied to obtain the relevant kinetic constants (i.e., ka, kd, kDa). Furthermore, a proteomic analysis was done comparing the RNA recognition motifs (RRMs) of both U1A mutants and another critical subunit in the U1 snRNP.

Download Poster (PDF)
Methods & Tools
Surface Plasmon Resonance · PCR · Bacterial Cell Culture · R (programming language) · TraceDrawer · Microsoft Word/Excel/Powerpoint · GIMP · GraphPad Prism · BioRender


Microbiome gDNA analysis of non-infected and infected zombie ants using Illumina sequencing

Role: Undergraduate Student in Research-intensive Course
Professor: Dr. Anna Forsman · Genomics & Bioinformatics Cluster · University of Central Florida
Duration: January 2022 – May 2023


This study consisted of extracting and analyzing gDNA from the inside of ant gut microbiomes. The ants of interest are known as “Zombie Ants” because of a unique disease they contract from a pathogenic fungus called Ophiocordyceps that causes them to change their behavior and commit suicide so to promote more growth of the fungi. The objective was to find if there are any differences between the gut microbiome of ants infected with Ophiocordyceps (a fungus that manipulates then kills), Beauveria (a fungus that simply kills) or a normal ant that was treated with a placebo. The gDNA was extracted from the ants using a Microprep Kit then ran through a two-step PCR protocol to amplify the extracted gDNA. Next, a SpeedBead cleanup protocol was run to separate the loose primers/small fragments from the amplified gDNA to increase sequencing data quality. Finally, sequencing was performed using an in-house Illumina platform and the data was analyzed using QIIME 2 to cross-reference with BLAST in order to determine the genetic diversity present.

Methods & Tools
Illumina Sequencing · PCR · QIIME · Agarose Gel Electrophoresis · Microsoft Word/Excel

title: Research
text:
Research Interests
My primary interests are in neuropharmacogenomics pertaining to the expression of neurodegenerative diseases and mental health disorders. In particular, sequence analysis, variant interpretation, and building reproducible pipelines for high-throughput biological data is a major focus of mine. I’m drawn to work at the intersection of algorithmic problem-solving and biological discovery, and I’m actively developing the computational foundation to contribute to that kind of research.
View Projects → Contact Me
